Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Chemical Cartography in the Milky Way with APOGEE
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI and his team work on the scientific outcomes from the large and systematic survey for precision stellar elemental abundance analyses that is set out to map the spatial variations in the chemistry across the Milky Way Galactic disk. They employ the Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE) in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS)-III survey, which is a large-scale, near-infrared (H-band), high-resolution (R ~ 30,000), high signal-to-noise (>100) spectroscopic survey of Milky Way stellar populations. The survey covers wavelengths from 1.51-1.68 microns which is a region that includes useful absorption lines from about 15 chemical elements, including alpha, odd-numbered, and iron peak elements. A three-year bright-time observing campaign from 2011-2014 will enable APOGEE to observe about 100,000 giants stars across the Galactic bulge, disk and halo, with the vast majority of these stars in the disk. This large catalog of chemical abundance data for stars all across the Milky Way from APOGEE is used to address a number of key questions related to the chemistry of the Galactic disk.
The analysis of the data from the APOGEE pipeline gives the stellar parameters (e.g., effective temperatures, gravity, metallicity) and abundances for about 15 elements which are used to deduce additional stellar properties (star-by-star extinctions, distances, ages) that are needed to map the abundances in the disk and to constrain models of Galactic chemical evolution. These maps provide the three-dimensional distributions represent an order of magnitude improvement in what has been achieved before in terms of numbers of stars included, numbers of chemical elements probed, homogeneity in the collection, reduction, and calibration of the data, and spatial coverage, including vast regions of the disk never before probed because of the limitations from dust.
As part of this work, the team plans to release a value-added APOGEE catalog of extinctions, distances and age estimates, along with the APOGEE data on abundances of about 15 chemical elements for about 100,000 stars from the thin and thick disks, and the reduction of these data into multidimensional maps of elemental abundances. These data should have significant value to the wider community of Galactic chemical evolution modelers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has supported the construction of chemical maps of our Milky Way galaxy. This was achieved using data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) Apache Point Observatory Galactic Evolution Experiment (APOGEE). APOGEE provides spectra taken in the near-infrared portion of the spectra, and such spectra were obtained for over a hundred thousand stars across the Milky Way. The main stellar targets are red giant stars that can be observed to large distances, and working in the near-infrared allows the survey to peer through the dust in the plane of the Milky Way that obscures our view in optical light. 

The APOGEE spectra have numerous features that allow us to measure not on the basic stellar parameters -- effective temperature and surface gravity -- but also the abundance of multiple different chemical elements in the atmospheres of the stars. These measurements allowed us to recognize that the chemistry of stars in the Galaxy varies with location: the inner portion of the Milky Way disk has more abundant heavy elements than the outer regions on average. However, not all stars in any given region have the same abundance of heavy elements, and the variations in the distribution of heavy elements across the Galaxy allowed us to infer that it is likely that some stars have moved from their birth locations in a process called radial migration.  In addition, the pattern of elemental abundances varies systematically with location in the Galaxy: in the inner regions, the abundances seem to indicate an earlier epoch of star formation than in the outer regions. The details of the abundance pattern variations help to constrain models of how the Milky Way formed and evolved.

Understanding how the Milky Way formed and evolved is a key question in astrophysics, especially since the Milky Way seems like a fairly typical galaxy, so it may be able to be used as a type of Rosetta Stone to understand some of the processes that are important in galaxy formation and evolution in general.

Beyond the astrophysics, this work required the analysis of spectra of several hundred thousand stars, working from the raw data to the extraction of the individual elemental abundances. This was a significant computational project, and some of the techniques that we developed may have applications both within astrophysics, and perhaps, for other fields.

Several graduate students were involved in the project, and their involvement was both productive for the project (they led several papers) and for their personal development (two went on to postdoctoral positions in the field).
